title: S&P 500, Dow on Track for Fourth Weekly Loss; Investors parse earnings from Chevron and Caterpillar at the end of a roller-coaster week
text:
Chevron reported its most profitable year since 2014 and said it would raise capital expenditures by 20% to $15 billion this year. Shares fell 1.6% in premarket trading. Caterpillar edged down after the company reported a surge in costs, offsetting a jump in revenue.

Apple shares rose 4.1% ahead of the bell after the biggest U.S. company by market capitalization posted record revenue and profits. Shares of brokerage Robinhood Markets, which reported a quarterly loss of $423 million, dropped 14% premarket.

Chairman Jerome Powell added to expectations the central bank will start a series of interest-rate increases in March after the Fed's policy meeting Wednesday. His comments pushed up yields on short-term government bonds, boosted the dollar and injected renewed turbulence into a stock market that has grown accustomed to monetary stimulus.

"Cheap money is like a comfort blanket for investors and for markets," said Jane Foley, senior foreign-exchange strategist at Rabobank. "Almost inevitably, you start to withdraw some of that cheap money and you're going to have more volatility in the markets."

The ICE Dollar Index, which tracks the greenback against other major currencies, rose 0.1% Friday. Up 1.8% for the week, it was on course for its biggest gain since June.

Government-bond prices fell, pushing up yields. The yield on interest-rate sensitive two-year Treasury notes ticked up to 1.216% from 1.190% Thursday and 0.993% at the end of last week. Yields on 10-year notes haven't risen as fast, which some analysts interpret as a sign investors think interest-rate rises by the Fed will squelch economic growth. They stood at 1.842% Friday, up from 1.747% a week ago.

Stocks have been choppy despite another solid round of earnings. Almost a third of the companies on the S&P 500 have reported fourth-quarter results and 78% of them have beaten analysts' estimates for earnings per share, according to FactSet.

In other premarket moves, Visa rose 4.3% after beating analysts' forecasts for profits and sales. Mondelez International slipped 2.2%. The food company said higher prices for its snacks weren't enough to make up for increased ingredient and transportation costs.

Investors will parse consumer-spending data from the Commerce Department at 8:30 a.m. ET. Economists expect the figures to show spending fell in December as rising coronavirus infections dented demand. Also due at 8:30 a.m., the Fed's preferred inflation gauge is forecast to show a continuation of the price pressures that have pushed the central bank to unwind stimulus.

Write to Joe Wallace at joe.wallace@wsj.com

S&P 500, Dow on Track for Fourth Weekly Loss
